title: 50's french diamond lineal lettering
content:
Hey,

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mode_6217.png)

I found this lettering in " La lettre dans la peinture et la publicité" of J. Joveneaux, edited in 1957 by Charles Massin (Paris).  
I'm looking for a similar digital typeface.  
Thank's for any help.
author: s.degeilh

comments.content:
Nick Curtis has a faceted font. Double D NF, which has a similar effect:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/double-d-nf/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/double-d-nf/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/double-d-nf/")  
For a previous discussion of this type of font see:  
 [http://typophile.com/node/105300](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/typophile.com/node/105300 "http://typophile.com/node/105300")  
Searches for faceted, bevelled and prismatic turn up other similar fonts.  
Don

Some I like in the same vein: [Faux](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.playtype.com/font/faux-occident), [PopUps](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.dafont.com/popups.font), [Fantablock Beveled](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/okaycat/3d-fantablock-beveled), [Brannt](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontry/race1-brannt) Chiseled, [Finkl](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.tendollarfonts.com/search.php?search_query=finkl), [Konkrete](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontry/fty-konkrete) Race Chisel, [Fire Down Below](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/fire-down-below-nf), [Marquee](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/pelavin/marquee), [Carved Initials](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/gallofonts/carved-initials), [Double D](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/double-d-nf) Outline, [Irrelevante](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/irrelevante), [Prismatic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/matchandkerosene/prismatic), [Detroit](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/matchandkerosene/detroit), [Turnpike Bevel](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/http:/www.thetypefoundry.com/fonts/turnpike-bevel)

The lettering was probably derived from the font Diament designed by J. Lehmann for Shiftgruss in 1937. It seems identical to Diament except for a narrower stroke width. Diament seems not to have been digitized.  
Don

Thanks for help.  
The Lehmann's Diamant aspect is really near.  
I think Turnpike should work.  
If anyone found better, let me know...  
SD

Hi Ryuk. As usual you have posted a good selection. Link for Faux Occident should be  
 [https://www.playtype.com/font/faux-occident](http://web.archive.org/web/20150403064309/https:/www.playtype.com/font/faux-occident "https://www.playtype.com/font/faux-occident")  
BTW Playtype's flashing image is very offputting. Can't see how it helps sales.  
Don
I think i saw that font in a MECANORMA book
